svg.text: A key activitiy in Europeana Newspapers
was the refinement of digitised newspaper
and Optical Layout Recognition in order
to produce electronic and fully searchable
text from scanned newspaper images. The
ambitious goal of the project was to apply
on pages, and accordingly technical project
partners with great experience in such refi-
nement were selected for the processing of
the newspaper pages. Organising the refine-
ment of over 10 million newspaper pages
required a very clear and highly standardi-
sed workflow to ensure that all parties are
aware of their tasks at all times and can al-
ways track the data at any point in the defi-
ned workflow. In the first year of the
ons of the partners were analysed and suita-
ble materials for refinement selected. In the
first year, a clear and strict specification
about the way files and folders had to be
provided by libraries in order to make the
subsequent refinement processes run as au-
tomated and smoothly as possible. To faci-
litate the necessary pre-processing of local
data to meet the requirements set out in the
specification, a number of supporting soft-
ware tools were created which have
since also been released as open source.
process of identifying and classifying entities
such as persons, locations and organisations
in a text in order to enhance searchability.
For Europeana Newspapers, it was decided
to produce NER for newspapers in three
Further to that, the project experimented
with more advanced ways to refine the NER
results by disambiguation and linking of
the extracted entities to authority files. In
the long run this will allow for a much more
All software and data for NER can also be
the National Library of the Netherlands.
A film was produced in cooperation
narrating the story of Walter Flex, war
volunteer from the start and one of the
best-known writers of the First World
literary remains, kept in the Staatsbiblio-
thek zu Berlin, have now been digitized
and are freely accessible in Europeana.
You can watch the full 18-minute movie

organised by participants in their own
country and local language, to make sure the
project and its activities are well embedded
in the various national newspaper and
European digital historical newspapers available via
